author: The Telegraph
title: Top 10: the best family-friendly hotels in Cornwall
text: Bedruthan Steps, Mawgan Porth Bedruthan Steps overlooks the superb beach, Mawgan Porth, with its huge expanse of golden sand at low tide. Though the hotel feels grown-up and there are adult-only relaxation and games rooms, dining areas and a cocktail bar, there are also all the facilities, clubs and activities that children could want. For the smallest there’s freshly made baby food, equipment from baby packs to bottle warmers, baby sitters and baby listening and toddlers’ play areas. Read the full review: Bedruthan Steps, Cornwall • The best hotels in Cornwall The Headland Hotel, Newquay With its luxury family-friendly accommodation in self-catering cottages close to the main hotel, The Headland is a great location for family holidays. There are indoor and outdoor pools, mini football field, tennis courts, putting, games and DVDs to borrow, body boards, buckets and spades and activity programmes during school holidays. And Fistral Beach is right there, where the Fistral Beach Surf School offers lessons for all ages. Read the full review: The Headland Hotel, Newquay Watergate Bay Hotel, Newquay The only hotel on Watergate Bay, a two-mile stretch of beach near Newquay, with fabulous views in both directions and the beach laid out just below. This is an entirely family-oriented hotel, with an appropriately laid-back and unfussy attitude. There are organised games, craft and activities, as well as evening entertainment in the ‘Kid’s Zone’ and ‘XA Club’, plus an indoor/oudoor pool and two miles of sandy beach outside the door, surf and many other watersport lessons at the Extreme Academy. Read the full review: Watergate Bay Hotel, Newquay The Old Coastguard, Penzance Stunningly situated above the harbour wall at Mousehole, with views from the restaurant of the palm-filled garden sloping down to the sea. While there are no particular facilities for children, it has an open-door policy for children who can scamper around the large tropical garden and enjoy the delights of Mousehole and the coast. There’s no charge for cots and children over five can sleep in a camp bed. One double room has an adjoining twin, perfect for families. Read the full review: The Old Coastguard, Penzance • The best hotels in Cornwall The Cornwall, St Austell The nine-bedroom hotel, which occupies the handsome 19th century White House, was superbly designed by AWW architects of Bristol and succeeds in being both user-friendly and striking. Tennis coaching from a resident expert is available on the courts behind the spa; complimentary films (with popcorn) are shown each evening in the school holidays; and a 20-riddle treasure trail is laid out in the 45 acres of grounds, in which children can discover the history behind the hotel. Equipment for babies and toddlers, from cots to potties, is available and there are family rooms. Read the full review: The Cornwall, St Austell Tresanton Hotel, St Mawes Set in what was a rambling former yacht club in St Mawes, Hotel Tresanton has marvellous views over Falmouth Bay. Though this is a sophisticated small hotel, children are welcome. There are three family suites, a children’s playroom and next to it, a children’s garden and lovely Wendy house. Children can watch films on a big screen in the hotel’s cinema, and during school holidays, there is a children’s club with arts and craft activities in the playroom or games on the beach. Read the full review: Tresanton Hotel, St Mawes • The best hotels in Cornwall St Enodoc, Rock The hotel, built in 1924 as a private house, is plain, but it enjoys an elevated position overlooking the Camel Estuary. St Enodoc is one of those seaside hotels that gets the balance right, and children here are as happy as their parents are comfortable. It’s not a child-centric hotel as such, but offers the services of a private surf instructor, perfect for a friendly and gentle introduction to the sport. Children’s meals are available in Outlaw’s, and there is a games room, including ping pong and table football, for rainy days. Read the full review: St Enodoc, Rock Fowey Hall, Fowey Set in landscaped gardens on a bluff above the sailing town of Fowey in south Cornwall, the hotel has far-reaching sea views. Trained nannies run the Four Bears Den, offering up to two hours free childcare per day for children up to eight. There’s plenty for older children too, including an indoor pool, zipwire and trampoline as well as watersports and the run of its beautiful grounds. Small children can sleep free in their parents’ room. Read the full review: Fowey Hall, Fowey • The best hotels in Cornwall Hell Bay, Isle of Scilly Hell Bay hotel offers wonderful views over two rocky bays, a saltwater lagoon and the open Atlantic Ocean. There's a choice of family suites with separate bedroom or chair-beds in the sitting area. Children from two to 12 pay £60 for B&B and high tea. The family dog is also welcome. Children can roam as they please on this traffic-free island. The grounds contain a heated outdoor pool, a multi-use games area (tennis, football, basketball) and there are organised watersports including kayaking, snorkelling and diving. Read the full review: Hell Bay, Isle of Scilly Polurrian Bay, Mullion Perched on the edge of a high cliff outside the village of Mullion, Polurrian Bay has wonderful sunsets over the Land’s End peninsula. There's a fully-staffed crèche for children over three months, high tea and baby listening so parents can enjoy a romantic dinner. New this year is an outdoor playzone for adults and children, with giant chess and snakes and ladders. During school holidays there are supervised evening Den activities for older children. You can even borrow buckets, spades and crab lines to take down to the private beach below. Read the full review: Polurrian Bay, Mullion • The best hotels in Cornwall Telegraphtravel Follow @telegraphtravel
